questions.text: Identify the congenital disc anomaly depicted in the image below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image depicts a morning glory disc.

  • Morning glory disc is a rare congenital optic disc anomaly named for its resemblance to the morning glory flower. It features a funnel-shaped central excavation of the optic disc, encircled by an elevated ring of chorioretinal disturbance.
  • A tuft of white glial tissue commonly overlies the central region, representing residual hyaloid vasculature. Retinal vessels radiate outward from the disc margin in a spoke-like fashion, and their number is increased, often making differentiation between arteries and veins difficult.
  • Laterality and Genetic Consideration: It is typically unilateral and sporadic, but bilateral cases may occur and can be hereditary. A mutation in the PAX6 gene has been implicated.
  • Systemic Associations: Though uncommon, morning glory disc can be associated with systemic abnormalities, especially midline craniofacial defects, basal encephaloceles, and pituitary dysfunction. The most notable association is with frontonasal dysplasia.
  • Visual Function: Visual acuity in affected individuals ranges widely, from normal to severely impaired, depending on the severity of the anomaly.
  • Complications: Potential complications include serous retinal detachment in about 30% of cases and the development of choroidal neovascular membranes.

Explanation of other options:

Optic disc coloboma (Option A): Coloboma of the optic disc, which arises due to incomplete closure of the embryonic fissure, typically appears as a large, white, excavated defect at the inferior disc margin with irregular vessel distribution.

Optic nerve hypoplasia (Option C): A developmental anomaly marked by a decreased number of optic nerve fibres, leading to varying degrees of visual impairment, from mild to profound. It is more frequently seen in children born to young first-time mothers.

Optic disc pit (Option D): A congenital anomaly where a small, round or oval depression is present on the optic disc, most often located temporally. It can be unilateral or bilateral and may be associated with a larger-than-normal disc.

choices.text: Males are more frequently involved than females
Vision loss is progressive throughout life

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Leber Hereditary Optic Neuropathy is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Leber hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON) affects males more commonly than females, as it is a mitochondrial disorder.

  • Leber hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON) is a mitochondrial DNA-linked inherited optic neuropathy, typically affecting young males with acute or subacute vision loss, often bilateral, leading to temporal or total disc pallor.
  • LHON typically presents around the age of 20, with vision loss that may start in one eye and progress to the other within weeks to months. Although it is an inherited condition, a clear family history may not always be apparent. (Option B ruled out)
  • The disorder is maternally inherited due to mutations in mitochondrial DNA, often passed by asymptomatic female carriers. About 50-70% of sons and 10-15% of daughters manifest symptoms, but sons cannot transmit the condition.
  • Vision loss begins with a central or centrocecal scotoma, eventually leading to severe loss of central vision, although complete blindness is rare. The peripheral visual field typically remains intact.
  • Fundus examination may appear normal initially or show slight disc swelling and small telangiectatic vessels that do not leak on fluorescein angiography. Over time, optic atrophy develops, especially involving the temporal disc.
  • Despite significant vision impairment, patients usually maintain good general health apart from occasional headaches. Blood testing for known LHON mutations is useful for diagnosis. Currently, no specific treatment is available, but genetic counselling is recommended. (Option C and D ruled out)

The image below shows the fundus examination findings in LHON.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a remnant of the hyaloid vasculature?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Synchisis scintillans is not a remnant of the hyaloid vasculature.

  • Remnants of the fetal hyaloid vascular system include structures such as Cloquet's canal, Mittendorf's dot, and Bergmeister's papilla.
  • Cloquet's canal is the path left behind by the regressing hyaloid artery in the primary vitreous, as shown below.
  • Mittendorf's dot is the anterior remnant seen on the posterior lens capsule, while Bergmeister's papilla is the fibrous tissue seen at the optic disc from remnants of the hyaloid artery.
  • The image given below depicts Mittendorf's dot and Bergmeister papillae, respectively.

  • In contrast, synchysis scintillans is unrelated to fetal vasculature. It is a degenerative condition seen in previously diseased or traumatised eyes, where multicoloured cholesterol crystals accumulate in the liquefied vitreous and may also appear in other eye chambers.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Cloquet canal (Option A): Incorrect. This is a central canal in the vitreous, a remnant of the primary hyaloid artery, running from the optic disc to the lens.

Bergmeister's papilla (Option B): Incorrect. This is a glial tuft on the optic disc, representing a remnant of the hyaloid artery's proximal portion.

Mittendorf's dot (Option C): Incorrect. This is a small opacity on the posterior lens capsule, representing a remnant of the distal hyaloid artery.

questions.text: Which is the commonest cause of inherited optic atrophy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Kjer's optic atrophy, also called dominant optic neuropathy, is the most frequent inherited disorder affecting the optic nerve.

  • Kier's optic atrophy typically begins between ages 5 and 10, with gradual and usually bilateral vision loss, although asymmetry between eyes is common.
  • Visual acuity can range from normal (6/6) to markedly reduced (as low as 6/60), though severe reduction is rare.
  • The vision loss generally progresses for a few years but stabilises after adolescence.
  • Associated features include central scotoma and impaired colour vision, but neurological signs are typically absent. It is important to differentiate it from other causes like compressive lesions, vitamin deficiencies, drug or toxin-related neuropathies, and a detailed family history or neuroimaging may assist in diagnosis if the inheritance pattern is unclear.

Explanation of other options:

Leber's optic atrophy(Option B): It follows mitochondrial inheritance and is less common than Kjer's. It typically presents in young adult males with more rapid and severe vision loss.

Wolfram syndrome(Option C): A form of complicated recessive hereditary optic neuropathy involving diabetes insipidus, diabetes mellitus, optic atrophy, and deafness (DIDMOAD).

Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease(Option D): A hereditary polyneuropathy that is associated with bilateral optic atrophy.

questions.text: Lateral geniculate body forms, which order neurons in the visual pathway?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lateral geniculate body forms the fourth-order neurons in the visual pathway.

  • In the visual pathway, signals from the retina reach the brain through a chain of neurons organised in sequential order.
  • The first-order neuron is formed by the photoreceptor cells of the retina, ie rods and cones. (Option A ruled out)
  • The second-order neuron is the retinal bipolar cell, which transmits signals to the retinal ganglion cells. (Option B ruled out)
  • The retinal ganglion cells, along with their axonal processes, which include the optic chiasm and optic tracts, form the third-order (Option C ruled out)
  • The optic nerve fibres synapse at the lateral geniculate body, which forms the fourth-order neuron that carries the impulses along the optic radiations to reach the occipital cortex, which functions as the primary visual processing centre.

questions.text: Descending bitemporal hemianopia is characteristic of?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Descending bitemporal hemianopia is characteristic of pituitary adenoma.

  • The nasal retinal fibres cross at the optic chiasm, and slow-growing pituitary adenomas typically exert pressure on the lower nasal optic fibres. This initially results in superior temporal quadrantanopia, which may later develop into bitemporal hemianopia. If a pituitary adenoma undergoes sudden infarction or bleeding (pituitary apoplexy), it can cause a rapid worsening of visual symptoms.
  • Heteronymous hemianopia refers to the loss of opposite halves of the visual field in both eyes and is classified into two types:
  • Binasal hemianopia: Loss of vision in the areas near the nose.
  • Bitemporal hemianopia: Loss of vision in the outer (temporal) visual fields.
  • The most frequent causes of bitemporal hemianopia, usually due to lesions affecting the central part of the optic chiasm, include:
  • Suprasellar aneurysms
  • Pituitary gland tumours
  • Craniopharyngiomas
  • Suprasellar meningiomas
  • Gliomas of the third ventricle
  • Lesions that affect the outer regions of the optic chiasm are uncommon. These lesions impact fibres from the temporal halves of the retina, leading to loss of vision in the nasal fields of one or both eyes, a condition known as binasal hemianopia.

Explanation of other options:

Optic neuritis (Option A): Visual field testing often shows a generalised reduction in sensitivity, especially in the central 30 degrees. Visual acuity is usually reduced to between 6/18 and 6/60, but can be worse. Colour vision is often affected, and a relative afferent pupillary defect may be seen.

Craniopharyngioma (Option B): Lesions such as craniopharyngiomas, which develop above the chiasm, typically affect the upper nasal fibres first, which present as inferior bitemporal hemianopia (ascending bitemporal hemianopia).

Glaucoma (Option D): Visual field defects in glaucoma include paracentral scotomas, arcuate defects, and ring scotoma. End-stage glaucoma is characterised by relatively preserved central vision.

questions.text: Homonymous Hemianopia is not seen in lesions of?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lesions of the optic chiasma lead to bitemporal hemianopia.

  • Retrochiasmal pathology leads to visual field loss in the visual space opposite to the lesion, affecting both eyes. This results in homonymous hemianopia, where the same side of the visual field is lost in each eye. This contrasts with bitemporal hemianopia from chiasmal compression, which is a heteronymous pattern with opposite field loss in each eye.
  • Right hemianopia is more quickly discovered than left, because reading is impossible. Left hemianopia is often discovered when the patient does not see food on the left side of the plate.
  • Congruity in Homonymous Hemianopia: Homonymous hemianopia can be complete or incomplete. Congruity refers to how similar the visual field defects are between the two eyes. Lesions in the posterior retrochiasmal pathway (e.g., optic radiations) produce highly congruous defects, while anterior lesions (e.g., optic tract) lead to incongruous ones. Near-identical field loss is termed highly congruous. (Option A and B ruled out)
  • The optic tracts arise at the posterior chiasm and project to the lateral geniculate body. Each tract contains nasal hemiretinal fibres from the contralateral eye and temporal fibres from the ipsilateral eye. These fibres do not align precisely, hence visual field defects tend to be incongruous. Damage in this area may also cause a Wernicke hemianopic pupil, where the pupillary light reflex is defective only when light is shone on the blind field.
  • Optic Radiations originate from the lateral geniculate body and transmit signals to the striate cortex in the occipital lobe. As fibres travel posteriorly, they become more organised, so lesions in the posterior segment produce more congruous defects.
  • Temporal (Meyer's Loop) Radiation Lesions: Lesions here produce contralateral superior homonymous quadrantanopia, often described as "pie in the sky," since the inferior fibres (representing upper visual fields) loop forward into the temporal lobe.
  • Anterior Parietal Radiation Lesions: These cause contralateral inferior homonymous quadrantanopia ("pie on the floor") because the superior fibres (lower field representation) travel posteriorly through the parietal lobe.
  • Main Radiation Lesions (Deep Parietal): Lesions deep in the parietal lobe near the trigone and occipital horn tend to cause complete homonymous hemianopia. These are typically highly congruous.
  • Lesions of the occipital cortex, commonly due to posterior cerebral artery lesions, lead to complete homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. This is because the area representing the central macular vision is supplied by the middle cerebral artery. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: The above visual field defect occurs due to a lesion of?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image depicts homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing seen in lesions of the occipital cortex.

  • The striate cortex (Brodmann area 17) or primary visual cortex is situated on the inner surface of the occipital lobe, positioned both superior and inferior to the calcarine fissure.
  • The central macular region is represented at the posterior tip of the calcarine cortex, mainly supplied by the middle cerebral artery. If the posterior cerebral artery is occluded, the central macular vision is often preserved, resulting in a congruous homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. (marked as "d"in the image)
  • Head trauma affecting the occipital cortex tip may lead to congruous homonymous macular visual field defects. (marked as"e" in the image)
  • Stroke is the most common cause of homonymous hemianopia without accompanying neurological deficits due to infarction in the posterior cerebral artery territory.
  • Other, less commonly, trauma, neoplasms, and migraine can affect the occipital lobe. Rare inflammatory conditions (autoimmune or infectious), degenerative diseases, and toxic insults may also lead to visual field loss but are generally associated with broader neurological symptoms.

Explanation of other options:

Parietal lobe (Option A): Lesions in the anterior parietal radiations lead to a contralateral inferior homonymous quadrantanopia, often described as "pie on the floor," since the superior optic radiation fibres, which are responsible for the lower visual field, pass backwards through the parietal lobe.

Temporal lobe (Option C): Damage to the temporal radiations, particularly Meyer's loop, results in a contralateral superior homonymous quadrantanopia, commonly referred to as "pie in the sky," because the lower fibres that correspond to the upper visual fields curve forward into the temporal lobe.

Optical radiation (Option D): Lesions located deep within the parietal lobe, near the trigone and occipital horn, usually result in a complete homonymous hemianopia, which is often highly congruous.

questions.text: Optic radiation arises from?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Optic radiation arises from the lateral geniculate body.

  • The optic nerve begins at the back of the eye, travels through the orbit, enters the optic canal, and then follows a variable path within the skull before meeting the optic nerve from the opposite side to form the optic chiasm.
  • The term "chiasm" refers to the X-shaped configuration where the two optic nerves join, allowing nasal retinal fibres to cross over to the opposite optic tract, while temporal retinal fibres continue on the same side.
  • As a result, visual input from the right visual field of both eyes is processed in the left hemisphere, and input from the left visual field is directed to the right hemisphere.
  • From the chiasm, the optic tracts carry signals to the lateral geniculate nuclei.
  • Axons originating in the lateral geniculate nuclei give rise to the optic radiations, which extend to the calcarine cortex. Within these radiations, fibres from the upper retina descend, while fibres from the lower retina ascend toward the visual cortex.

Explanation of other options:

Rods and cones (Option A): They are the photoreceptor cells of the retina, which form the first-order neuron in the visual pathway.

Bipolar cells (Option C): Bipolar cells present in the inner nuclear layer of the retina form the second-order neuron in the visual pathway.

Ganglion cells (Option D): Axons of the retinal ganglion cells form the optic nerve and become the third-order neuron of the visual pathway.

questions.text: A patient presents with a perimetry report showing left-sided central scotoma and right-sided superotemporal quadrantanopia as shown below. Likely site of lesion is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical vignette and perimetry findings are suggestive of a junctional scotoma of Traquair, which arises due to lesions of the optic nerve on the side of the central scotoma and anterior angle of the optic chiasma. (Option A, C, and D ruled out)

Junctional scotoma is characterised by a central scotoma or total vision loss in one eye, along with a superotemporal visual field defect in the opposite eye.

Additionally, hemianopic arcuate scotomas can be an early sign of anterior chiasmal compression. Anterior junctional syndrome can be seen in conditions such as sphenoid meningioma.

This characteristic pattern is thought to result from a structural configuration in the optic chiasm known as Wilbrand's knee. This loop represents a temporary path taken by the inferior nasal retinal fibres as they briefly enter the opposite optic nerve before continuing into the contralateral optic tract.

choices.text: Increase in latency and amplitude of response
Decrease in latency and amplitude of response
Increase in latency and decrease in amplitude of response
Decrease in latency and increase in amplitude of response

questions.text: Which of the following findings can be seen in visual evoked potentials in optic nerve disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Optic nerve disease is characterised by an increase in latency and a decrease in amplitude of response in visual evoked potentials.

  • Visual evoked potentials (VEPs), also referred to as visual evoked responses (VERs), are recordings of electrical activity in the visual cortex triggered by retinal stimulation.
  • These responses are captured using electronic averaging techniques and are particularly useful in evaluating visual pathway integrity.
  • The stimulus for VEP can be either unstructured (e.g., a flashing light - flash VEP) or structured, such as a pattern (commonly a checkerboard) displayed on a monitor that reverses contrast (pattern VEP).
  • Flash VEP: A basic, non-specific test that confirms light perception. It reflects a broad foveal response and is unaffected by opacities in the cornea or lens. Flash VEP is especially valuable when only one eye is suspected of pathology and helps assess general macular or optic nerve integrity.
  • Pattern Reversal VEP: This test specifically evaluates the central visual pathways (fovea-dependent) and can provide a rough approximation of visual acuity.
  • Principle and Applications: VEP is used to assess visual function in infants, detect optic neuropathy (especially in demyelinating conditions) and investigate functional visual loss. It also evaluates macular pathway integrity.
  • Interpretation: Latency refers to the time delay between stimulus and cortical response, and amplitude measures the strength of the response.
  • In optic neuropathies, both parameters are often affected: latency is prolonged, and amplitude is reduced. These findings are particularly important in retrobulbar neuritis, where delayed latency can persist even after visual recovery, providing a clue to prior demyelinating events.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Increase in latency and amplitude of response (Option A): Incorrect. In optic nerve disease, conduction is slowed and axonal loss may occur, so amplitude typically decreases, not increases.

Decrease in latency and amplitude of response (Option B): Incorrect. Latency is prolonged in demyelinating or compressive optic neuropathies, so a decrease in latency does not occur.

Decrease in latency and increase in amplitude of response (Option D): Incorrect. Both features are opposite to what is seen in optic nerve disease; latency is prolonged and amplitude reduced, not shortened and increased.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman developed blurred vision in the left eye while trying to read the newspaper around 2 months ago and has presented to the OPD now. On examination, she has a mid-dilated pupil that reacts only to near stimulus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diagnosis based on the given clinical vignette is Adie’s pupil.

  • Adie’s tonic pupil arises due to damage to either the ciliary ganglion or short ciliary nerves, an example of postganglionic
  • It commonly affects young women who present with a dilated pupil and blurred near vision due to impaired accommodation.
  • Segmental denervation of the iris sphincter can be seen on slit-lamp examination.
  • It can follow a viral illness and is inherited in an autosomal-dominant pattern.
  • Cholinergic supersensitivity, e. exaggerated response to parasympathetic drugs such as pilocarpine, can be demonstrated within the first week.
  • In a couple of months, the pupil becomes miotic due to aberrant regeneration of the ciliary muscle fibres to the iris sphincter.
  • This leads to the characteristic light-near dissociation seen in Adie's tonic pupil. (the pupil fails to constrict in response to light but constricts normally (though sluggishly and tonically) during near vision/ accommodation)
  • Adie's syndrome is also associated with impaired deep tendon reflexes.

Other causes of light-near dissociation include:

  • Unilateral causes: Afferent conduction defect, Herpes zoster ophthalmicus, Aberrant regeneration of the third cranial nerve
  • Bilateral causes: Neurosyphilis, Type 1 diabetes mellitus, Myotonic dystrophy, Parinaud (dorsal midbrain) syndrome

Explanation of other options:

Third cranial nerve palsy (Option A): Third nerve palsy presents with ptosis, resulting from paralysis of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle. In primary gaze, the affected eye typically appears deviated "down and out" due to the unopposed actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles.

Horner's syndrome (Option B): Typically presents unilaterally and results from disruption of the sympathetic pathway. Common signs include mild ptosis (1 -2 mm) due to weakness of Muller's muscle and miosis from unopposed sphincter pupillae activity, producing anisocoria, especially noticeable in dim lighting.

Argyll-Robertson pupil (Option D): Typically associated with neurosyphilis and results from a lesion in the dorsal midbrain that disrupts the light reflex pathway but spares the near reflex pathway, leading to light-near dissociation. Clinically, the pupils are small, may appear irregular, and do not constrict in response to light. However, they constrict during accommodation when focusing on a near object.

These pupils do not dilate well in darkness, though cocaine drops may still cause dilation unless severe iris atrophy is present. Notably, after administering 0.1% pilocarpine, there is no response, which helps differentiate them from bilateral Adie's tonic pupils, where constriction would occur.

questions.text: A patient with vertical diplopia has normal pupil size and reactions, negative forced duction testing and abnormal saccades. Which of the following causes is the most likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diagnosis based on the given clinical vignette is myasthenia gravis.

  • Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder characterised by the immune system producing antibodies that damage acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.
  • This leads to muscle weakness and fatigue, primarily affecting voluntary muscles such as those controlling eye movement and the bulbar muscles involved in speech and swallowing.
  • Since the involuntary muscles are spared, pupillary reactions and size remain normal.
  • The condition is more common in women and tends to develop in young adults, with a higher incidence of ocular symptoms. It is often associated with other autoimmune conditions and may be linked to thymic abnormalities.
  • Ocular myasthenia is seen in about 90% of cases, with ptosis being a common feature present in around 60% of patients. This eyelid drooping is typically bilateral, insidious, and often worsens by the end of the day or with sustained activity. Additional symptoms include a brief upward movement of the eyelid known as Cogan's twitch sign, which occurs as the eyes shift from a downward to a primary position.
  • Diplopia (commonly vertical), nystagmus, strabismus, and abnormal saccades are other ocular features.

Explanation of other options:

6th nerve palsy (Option A): Leads to restrictive ophthalmoplegia in which the forced duction test is usually positive. Presents with esotropia in the primary position and compensatory face turn towards the side of the paralysed muscle.

Thyroid eye disease(Option B): Thyroid eye disease leads to restrictive eye disease, which gives a positive forced duction test.

Chronic orbital myositis(Option D): An idiopathic, non-specific inflammation of extraocular muscles, which can lead to permanent restrictive myopathy in chronic cases.

choices.text: Use of cholinergic (pilocarpine-like) drops in the right eye
Use of anticholinergic (atropine like substance) drops in the right eye

questions.text: A farmer presents to you with blurred vision, especially in dim light. Examination of both eyes is normal except for the presence of a 1.5 mm, nonreactive right pupil. The left pupil is 4 mm and briskly reactive and does not dilate in darkness. She has no ptosis and normal ocular motility. The anterior chamber has no cells or flare. What is the most likely aetiology?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario of blurred vision and fixed miotic pupils suggests the use of cholinergic drops in the eye.

  • Miotics are drugs that act as cholinergic agonists and are primarily used to manage angle-closure glaucoma. In cases of angle-closure glaucoma, miotics work by contracting the sphincter pupillae muscle, which draws the peripheral iris away from the trabecular meshwork, thus helping to open the drainage angle.
  • Additionally, they lower intraocular pressure (IOP) by stimulating contraction of the ciliary muscle, thereby enhancing the outflow of aqueous humour through the trabecular meshwork.
  • Common local adverse effects include pupil constriction (miosis), brow discomfort, a myopic shift, and worsening of cataract symptoms.
  • These changes can make visual field defects seem larger and more intense. Although rare, systemic side effects may involve confusion, a slowed heart rate (bradycardia), bronchospasm, gastrointestinal issues, and increased urinary frequency.

Explanation of other options:

Use of anticholinergic(atropine like substance) drops in the right eye (Option B): Anticholinergic drops cause dilatation of the pupils, which do not constrict in response to light, hence this option can be ruled out.

Horner's syndrome (Option C): Horner's syndrome results in miotic pupils that dilate in darkness but very slowly. This causes anisocoria accentuated by dim light. Other features include mild ptosis and enophthalmos.

Uveitis (Option D): Miosis due to pupillary spasm can be seen in uveitis, but since other features such as painful red eye and aqueous flare are absent, this option can be ruled out.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in a 60-year-old man who awakens after cardiac bypass surgery with decreased vision in the right eye, a right relative afferent pupillary defect and normal fundoscopy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diagnosis based on the given clinical vignette of reduced vision, relative afferent pupillary defect, and history of cardiac bypass surgery is posterior ischemic optic neuropathy.

  • Posterior ischaemic optic neuropathy (PION), which is less frequent than the anterior form, results from reduced blood supply to the retro-laminar section of the optic nerve.
  • This portion is nourished by the pial capillary network derived from the pial branches of the ophthalmic artery. Since only a limited number of capillaries reach into the central portion of the nerve, this region is particularly vulnerable.
  • Diagnosis of PION should be considered only after excluding other causes of retrobulbar optic neuropathy, such as compressive or inflammatory conditions. Initially, the optic disc appears normal, but pallor becomes evident over the following weeks.
  • There are three forms of PION: operative, arteritic, and non-arteritic. Operative PION arises after surgeries, especially cardiac and spinal procedures, with a low occurrence rate of around 0.02%. Major contributing factors include anaemia and intraoperative hypotension, and it often affects both eyes with a poor visual outcome. Early intervention with blood transfusion or managing orbital oedema may help.
  • Arteritic PION, typically linked with giant cell arteritis (GCA), carries a poor prognosis.
  • Non-arteritic PION shares systemic risk factors with NAION, such as diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia, but lacks a crowded optic disc and usually has a similar visual outcome. Some clinicians may initiate high-dose systemic corticosteroids early in these cases.

Explanation of other options:

Optic neuritis (Option B): Vision loss in optic neuritis usually occurs abruptly and is most often confined to one eye. The visual decline generally progresses over several days and tends to peak within three weeks before showing signs of recovery. Visual field testing often shows an overall drop in sensitivity, with the most notable impairments concentrated within the central 20 degrees, presenting in various patterns. It is associated with painful movements of the eye and commonly affects the age group 20 - 40.

Cilioretinal artery occlusion (Option C): A cilioretinal artery, present in about one-third of individuals, can preserve central vision in cases of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) if it supplies the fovea, and its occlusion may occur in isolation or alongside conditions like central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) or anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION) with varying prognoses. Fundus examination in CRVO shows extensive flame-shaped haemorrhages and cotton wool spots. AION is associated with altitudinal visual field defects.

Occipital lobe lesion (Option D): Lesions affecting the occipital lobe characteristically present as congruous homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman has anisocoria that is greater in light. The right pupil is sluggishly reactive to light, and she has normal ocular motility, alignment and normal eyelid position. There is no history of using eye drops. What would be the next best step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The next best step in a case of anisocoria greater in light is slit lamp examination.

Anisocoria greater in light indicates a defect in the parasympathetic pathway or pupillary sphincter, as the dilated pupil remains so while the unaffected pupil undergoes constriction, which makes the anisocoria more prominent.

Causes include pharmacological mydriasis, Adie's tonic pupil, third nerve palsy, and trauma causing damage to the pupillary sphincter.

Pharmacological mydriasis can be ruled out since there is no history of using eye drops.

Normal eyelid position and normal alignment in primary gaze rule out third nerve palsy.

To differentiate between Adie's tonic pupil and trauma causing damage to the pupillary sphincter, the best investigation among the given options is slit lamp microscopy.

Explanation of other options:

10% cocaine eye drops (Option A): Useful in testing for Horner's syndrome, which is unlikely here as pupils in Horner's syndrome show sluggish dilation in the dark.

MRA brain (Option C): Useful if third nerve palsy is suspected. Here, it is unlikely given the normal lid position and absence of a down and out pupil in primary gaze.

Carotid ultrasonography (Option D): Can be used to diagnose dissecting carotid aneurysms, which can lead to Horner's syndrome.

choices.text: Efferent pupillary pathway defect is suspected
Relative afferent pathway defect is suspected
Defect in the refractive media of the eye is suspected
Absolute afferent pathway defect is suspected

questions.text: The swinging Flash Light Test is performed when?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The swinging flashlight test is suspected when a relative afferent pathway defect is suspected.

  • A Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect (RAPD), also known as Marcus Gunn pupil, arises due to partial optic nerve dysfunction or severe retinal disease.
  • This defect is detected using the swinging flashlight test, where a light is moved quickly between the two eyes in a dark room while observing their pupillary response.
  • In a healthy eye, both pupils constrict equally when illuminated. However, when the light is directed at the eye with an afferent defect, both pupils may paradoxically dilate due to decreased sensory input, revealing the RAPD.
  • Test Technique and Interpretation: The light source should be slightly dim and angled below the patient's line of sight at 45°. As the light is alternated every 2 - 3 seconds between the eyes, both pupils should constrict equally with each swing. In RAPD, the defective eye shows a consistently weaker response compared to the normal one, either by constricting less or dilating (known as "pupillary escape"). To distinguish subtle differences, the test may be repeated four to five times. The test should ideally be performed in a darkened room with an indirect ophthalmoscope or flashlight.
  • Consensual vs Direct Response: A key concept in interpreting the test is comparing the direct response of each eye to its consensual response. If the consensual response (pupil constriction in the opposite eye) is stronger than the direct response (in the illuminated eye), a RAPD is present in the eye receiving the light stimulus. If the reverse is true, the other eye is affected.
  • RAPD occurs commonly in unilateral optic neuropathies and severe macular disease (when asymmetric). It is frequently found in chiasmal lesions and nearly always in optic tract disease (contralateral to the affected tract, as the contralateral temporal hemifield is larger than the ipsilateral nasal field)
  • It may be seen in retrogenicular lesions or severe amblyopia, but it never occurs in simple refractive errors. A transient RAPD may appear when an eye is uncovered after dark adaptation.

Explanation of other options:

Efferent pupillary pathway defect (Option A): Is marked by anisocoria and cannot be detected with the swinging flashlight test, which detects afferent pathway defects.

Defect in the refractive media of the eye is suspected (Option C): RAPD is never present in such cases, and hence swinging flashlight test is not done.

Absolute afferent pathway defect is suspected (Option D): An absolute afferent pupillary defect, also known as an amaurotic pupil, arises due to complete damage to the optic nerve and presents with total blindness in the affected eye. Despite the profound visual loss, both pupils remain equal in size. When light is directed at the blind eye, neither pupil shows a constrictive response and hence cannot be detected by the swinging flashlight test. However, if the unaffected eye is illuminated, both pupils constrict normally, indicating that the efferent pathways are intact. Additionally, the near reflex remains preserved in both eyes.

questions.text: Absence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the affected side indicates?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The absence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the affected side indicates an efferent pathway defect.

The various other abnormalities of pupillary reaction are summarised below.

  • Amaurotic pupil: An amaurotic eye, or absolute afferent pupillary defect, results from complete optic nerve damage leading to total blindness in that eye. Although both pupils remain equal in size, light stimulation of the affected eye elicits no pupillary reaction in either eye, while stimulation of the healthy eye produces a normal bilateral response. Despite the visual loss, the near reflex remains intact in both eyes. (Option A ruled out)
  • Wernicke hemianopic pupil: Wernicke hemianopic pupil occurs due to an optic tract lesion affecting the afferent pupillary fibres, which diverge before reaching the lateral geniculate body and project to the pretectal nuclei. When light is directed at the hemianopic (involved) side, causing an absent pupillary reflex, while stimulation of the unaffected hemiretina elicits a normal response. (Option C ruled out)
  • Marcus Gunn pupil (RAPD): Relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), also called Marcus Gunn pupil, results from partial damage to the optic nerve or severe retinal pathology, but not from media opacities like cataracts. It is detected using the swinging flashlight test, where the pupils constrict when light is shone in the normal eye but paradoxically dilate when the light is moved to the affected eye due to reduced afferent input.
  • Argyll Robertson pupil: Argyll Robertson pupils are a result of neurosyphilis and are linked to a dorsal midbrain lesion that disrupts the light reflex pathway while sparing the near reflex pathway, producing light-near dissociation. Clinically, both pupils appear small and irregular in dim light and fail to constrict in response to bright light, but do constrict during near accommodation. These pupils do not dilate well in the dark, but respond to cocaine unless there is significant iris atrophy. They also do not respond to dilute pilocarpine (0.1%), which helps distinguish them from tonic pupils. (Option D ruled out)
  • Adie's tonic pupil: Adie tonic pupil is a condition resulting from damage to the postganglionic parasympathetic fibres supplying the sphincter pupillae and ciliary muscle, often following a viral illness or occurring sporadically in an autosomal dominant manner. It usually affects young women, and patients may present with anisocoria or blurred near vision due to accommodative dysfunction. Examination reveals a large, often regular pupil with sluggish or absent direct and consensual light reflexes, slow pupillary constriction to near stimuli followed by delayed redilation, and characteristic vermiform movements of the pupillary border on the slit lamp. In chronic cases, the pupil may shrink in size, known as ‘little old Adie'.

questions.text: Which of the following pupillary signs is seen after a concussion injury to the brain?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Hutchinson sign is seen in the pupil after a concussion injury to the brain.

  • Concussion injuries are associated with subdural haemorrhage and loss of consciousness and can present with two key ocular findings - the Hutchinson pupil and
  • Hutchinson's pupil begins with constriction of the pupil on the same side as the lesion, followed by dilation without a light reflex due to increased intracranial pressure.
  • If pressure continues to rise, the opposite pupil is similarly affected, and bilateral fixed dilated pupils signal the need for urgent brain decompression.
  • Papilledema, if it occurs within 48 hours post-trauma, points to intra- or extracerebral haemorrhage requiring immediate surgery, whereas delayed onset (after about a week) usually indicates cerebral oedema.

Explanation of other options:

Marcus Gunn pupil (Option A): Relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), also known as Marcus Gunn pupil, arises from incomplete optic nerve damage or significant retinal disease. It is identified with the swinging flashlight test, where shining light in the healthy eye causes normal constriction, but shifting it to the affected eye leads to a paradoxical dilation due to diminished sensory input.

Wernicke Hemianopic pupil (Option C): Wernicke hemianopic pupil arises from an optic tract lesion that disrupts the afferent pupillary fibres, which branch off before the lateral geniculate body and connect to the pretectal nuclei. As a result, shining light on the affected hemiretina fails to trigger a pupillary reaction, whereas stimulating the unaffected hemiretina produces a normal pupillary response.

Argyll Robertson Pupil (Option D): Argyll Robertson pupils are associated with neurosyphilis and stem from a dorsal midbrain lesion that impairs the light reflex pathway while preserving the near reflex, leading to light-near dissociation. In clinical settings, the pupils are typically small and irregular in low light, fail to constrict with bright light, but constrict appropriately during near focus. They show poor dilation in the dark, respond to cocaine unless severe iris atrophy is present, and do not constrict with 0.1% pilocarpine-helping to differentiate them from tonic (Adie) pupils.

questions.text: Paresis of SR and IO of the same eye occurs in?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Paresis of the superior rectus and inferior oblique of the same eye is seen in double elevator palsy.

  • Monocular elevation deficiency (MED), formerly referred to as double elevator palsy, is characterised by a functional weakness of both the superior rectus and inferior oblique muscles in one eye, leading to a noticeable downward deviation (hypotropia) that worsens with upward gaze.
  • Bell's phenomenon is typically absent in these cases, and if present, suggests a supranuclear origin. The condition does not usually affect the pupil or horizontal eye movements. It may be present from birth or acquired later in life, with acquired cases often linked to small lesions in the pretectal area, necessitating neuroimaging.
  • When diagnosing MED, it is important to distinguish it from mechanical limitations to upward eye movement, such as those caused by orbital floor fractures, thyroid eye disease, congenital fibrosis of the extraocular muscles, or Brown's syndrome, which can similarly affect vertical gaze in the primary position. To confirm or rule out mechanical restriction, forced duction testing is necessary.
  • Surgical management often involves transposing the medial and lateral rectus tendons to the superior rectus insertion (known as Knapp's procedure), which has been shown to improve vertical alignment while having minimal effect on horizontal movement.

Explanation of other options:

Mobius syndrome (option B): The hallmark features are congenital, non-progressive paralysis of both the abducens (sixth) and facial (seventh) nerves, which reflect an underlying developmental defect of the brainstem. In addition, other cranial nerves like the fifth, eighth, tenth, and twelfth may also be involved. Patients may also present with limb abnormalities and mild intellectual disability. Ocular involvement includes bilateral sixth nerve palsy, horizontal gaze palsy in half of the cases, and occasionally, third and fourth nerve palsies with ptosis.

Brown's syndrome (Option C): A motility disorder primarily involving restriction of elevation in adduction due to abnormalities in the tendon-trochlea complex of the superior oblique muscle. Initially attributed to a shortened tendon sheath, it is now believed to result from various mechanical anomalies. It more commonly affects females (3:2 ratio), tends to occur more often in the right eye, and is bilateral in about 10% of cases. Familial patterns have also been observed.

Duanne's retraction syndrome (Option D): Duane Retraction Syndrome results from a developmental abnormality in which the lateral rectus muscle, usually innervated by the abducens nerve (sixth cranial nerve), instead receives misdirected innervation from the oculomotor nerve (third nerve) due to a hypoplastic or absent sixth nerve nucleus. It is often bilateral and can be associated with systemic abnormalities such as hearing loss, skeletal or external ear anomalies, and speech disorders. Roughly 10% of cases have a familial link.

questions.text: Duane's Retraction Syndrome is characterised by?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Duane’s retraction syndrome is characterised by decreased function of the 6th nerve with limitation of abduction.

  • Duane Retraction Syndrome results from a developmental abnormality in which the lateral rectus muscle, usually innervated by the abducens nerve (sixth cranial nerve), instead receives misdirected innervation from the oculomotor nerve (third nerve) due to a hypoplastic or absent sixth nerve nucleus. It is often bilateral and can be associated with systemic abnormalities such as hearing loss, skeletal or external ear anomalies, and speech disorders. Roughly 10% of cases have a familial link. (Option A and B ruled out)
  • Clinical signs include limited or absent abduction, partially restricted adduction, and globe retraction with narrowing of the palpebral fissure during adduction due to co-contraction of horizontal rectus muscles. (Option D ruled out)
  • Abnormal vertical eye movement (up-shoot or down-shoot) may also be present. A compensatory head turn helps maintain binocular single vision.
  • Classification by Huber divides DRS into:

Type I: most common, with limited/absent abduction and normal/mildly limited adduction, often showing esotropia.

Type II: least common, shows limited adduction and normal/mildly limited abduction, with exotropia.

Type III: both adduction and abduction are limited, with straight or slightly esotropic alignment in primary gaze.

  • Treatment is generally not required unless there is a significant cosmetic concern or functional impairment. Young children often compensate well with a habitual head posture. Surgery may be needed for cosmetic correction, severe retraction, vertical deviations, or if binocular vision cannot be maintained.

questions.text: Which are the two most common extraocular muscles to get paralysed singly?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Superior oblique and lateral rectus are the two most common extraocular muscles to get paralysed in isolation.

  • Lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles are most frequently affected in isolated paralysis, primarily because each is innervated by a distinct cranial nerve.
  • In contrast, isolated involvement of the other four extraocular muscles is uncommon and typically occurs in congenital conditions.

Explanation of Incorrect options:

Inferior oblique and lateral rectus (Option B): Incorrect. The inferior oblique is rarely involved in isolated paralysis; lateral rectus can be affected singly, but this combination is uncommon.

Superior oblique and medial rectus (Option C): Incorrect. Isolated medial rectus palsy is very rare; superior oblique palsy is common, but this pairing is unusual.

Inferior oblique and medial rectus (Option D): Incorrect. Both muscles are rarely affected in isolation, making this combination extremely uncommon.

questions.text: Lesions at the level of motor nuclei sparing the Edinger-Westphal nucleus, cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lesions at the level of motor nuclei sparing the Edinger-Westphal nucleus, cause external ophthalmoplegia.

  • Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia encompasses a group of conditions primarily affecting the extraocular muscles and levator palpebrae superioris, manifesting as bilateral ptosis, often the initial symptom.
  • The disorder typically progresses gradually, with no periods of remission or exacerbation. Ocular motility progressively deteriorates, starting with limited upward gaze, followed by horizontal gaze, and can ultimately lead to near-total ophthalmoplegia.
  • Despite severe eye movement restriction, pupils are usually spared. Diplopia is uncommon due to the symmetrical nature of the motility loss, although patients may struggle with near tasks due to convergence issues. In some cases, CPEO occurs in isolation, while in others, it may be part of systemic syndromes like Kearns-Sayre syndrome or oculopharyngeal dystrophy.
  • Electromyographic findings suggest both myotonic and myopathic involvement, and raised serum creatine kinase levels support muscle pathology. Management is primarily supportive with physiotherapy to prevent contractures, though surgical intervention may help those with disabling diplopia.

Explanation of other options:

Internal ophthalmoplegia (Option A): Internal ophthalmoplegia refers specifically to the paralysis of intraocular muscles, namely the ciliary muscle and the sphincter pupillae, which control accommodation and pupillary constriction. This condition can arise from neuritis associated with infections such as diphtheria and syphilis, or from systemic disorders like diabetes mellitus and chronic alcoholism. It may also be linked to cerebral or meningeal pathology. These underlying conditions disrupt the parasympathetic innervation of the intraocular structures, leading to impaired near vision and an unresponsive pupil.

Total ophthalmoplegia (Option B): Complete paralysis of all extraocular muscles, including the levator palpebrae superioris (LPS), as well as intraocular muscles such as the sphincter pupillae and the ciliary muscle. This condition arises due to the simultaneous involvement of the third, fourth, and sixth cranial nerves. It is most commonly observed in conditions like orbital apex syndrome and cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (Option D): Results from damage to the medial longitudinal fasciculus, disrupting horizontal eye movement coordination between the sixth nerve nucleus in the pons and the contralateral third nerve nucleus in the midbrain, leading to impaired adduction of the eye on the same side as the lesion. While convergence is typically preserved, severe cases show complete adduction failure with nystagmus in the abducting eye, and bilateral involvement may produce a divergent eye position with upward gaze nystagmus, known as WEBINO (wall-eyed bilateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia).

questions.text: Which of the following does not cause a Horizontal gaze palsy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Steel Richardson Olszewski syndrome causes vertical gaze palsy.

Horizontal gaze palsy:

  • Anatomy and Pathway: Horizontal gaze is controlled by the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF), which sends signals directly to the ipsilateral sixth nerve nucleus and indirectly via the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) to the contralateral third nerve nucleus. This coordination ensures conjugate eye movement toward one side. A lesion in the PPRF leads to a horizontal gaze palsy on the same side as the lesion, resulting in an inability to look toward that side.
  • Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia (INO): Caused by lesions in the MLF, INO results in impaired horizontal eye coordination. In unilateral INO, the affected eye cannot adduct, and the opposite eye shows nystagmus during abduction. The primary position usually shows straight alignment, and convergence is often preserved unless the lesion is posterior or extensive. (Option A ruled out)
  • Bilateral INO: This results in impaired adduction of both eyes with nystagmus in the abducting eye. Convergence may or may not be affected. A lesion in the rostral midbrain may also lead to bilateral exotropia with abducting nystagmus, termed wall-eyed bilateral INO (WEBINO). (Option D ruled out)
  • One-and-a-Half Syndrome: This condition arises from a combined lesion of the PPRF and MLF on one side, producing horizontal gaze palsy on that side (the "one") and an internuclear ophthalmoplegia on attempted gaze to the opposite side (the "half"), where only abduction of the contralateral eye remains possible. (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following causes Vertical Gaze palsy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vertical gaze palsy results from lesions affecting the vertical gaze centres in the midbrain and manifests with impaired upward and/or downward eye movements, and can be seen in Parinaud syndrome.

  • Vertical gaze palsy involves difficulty in vertical eye movements due to lesions in the rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) in the midbrain. Both eyes are affected because the vertical gaze control is bilateral and coordinated.
  • In Parinaud syndrome, the hallmark features include supranuclear vertical gaze palsy (especially upgaze), impaired convergence, normal downgaze with doll's head manoeuvre, light-near dissociation of pupils, Collier's sign (lid retraction), and convergence-retraction nystagmus.
  • This condition arises from dorsal midbrain lesions, commonly due to aqueductal stenosis, pineal tumours, meningitis in children, demyelination and trauma in young adults, or vascular events and tumours in the elderly.
  • In contrast, progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP), also known as the Steele-Richardson-Olszewski syndrome, is a neurodegenerative disorder typically seen in older individuals. It initially causes downgaze palsy that later involves upgaze and eventually all gaze directions. Other key features of PSP include convergence loss, pseudobulbar palsy, and extrapyramidal signs such as rigidity, gait ataxia, and dementia. This results in a global gaze palsy with advancing disease.

Explanation of other options:

Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (Option A): Caused by lesions in the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) results in impaired horizontal eye coordination. In unilateral INO, the affected eye cannot adduct, and the opposite eye shows nystagmus during abduction. The primary position usually shows straight alignment, and convergence is often preserved unless the lesion is posterior or extensive.

One and half syndrome (Option B): This condition arises from a combined lesion of the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) and MLF on one side, producing horizontal gaze palsy on that side (the "one") and an internuclear ophthalmoplegia on attempted gaze to the opposite side (the "half"), where only abduction of the contralateral eye remains possible.

questions.text: Quadruple sectoranopia visual field defects are seen in lesions of?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lateral geniculate body (LGB) lesions can produce distinct homonymous visual field defects such as horizontal sectoranopia or quadruple sectoranopia, depending on the specific vascular territory affected.

  • Lesions of the lateral geniculate body (LGB), though rare, lead to unique homonymous visual field defects due to its precise anatomical and vascular organisation.
  • The LGB receives a dual vascular supply: the central region, representing the macular field, is nourished by the lateral choroidal artery, while the medial and lateral portions (corresponding to inferior and superior fields) are supplied by the distal anterior choroidal artery.
  • A lesion in the territory of the lateral choroidal artery causes a congruous homonymous horizontal sectoranopia, where the central visual fields are affected in a horizontal wedge shape.
  • On the other hand, infarction involving the distal anterior choroidal artery damages both the superior and inferior peripheral visual field representations, resulting in a congruous homonymous quadruple sectoranopia, where both upper and lower quadrants are lost but central vision remains intact. These defects respect vertical midlines and are sharply demarcated, often described as "keyhole" or wedge-shaped on visual field testing. This pattern reflects the precise retinotopic mapping and vascular segmentation within the LGB.

Explanation of other options:

Optic chiasma (Option A): Lesions of the optic chiasma lead to bitemporal hemianopia.

Optic nerve(Option B): Leads to ipsilateral anopia.

Occipital lobe (Option C): Characteristic lesion includes congruent homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing.

questions.text: The chart given below is used to assess?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given chart is the Pelli-Robson chart, which is used to assess contrast sensitivity.

  • Contrast sensitivity measures how well a person can distinguish subtle differences in luminance, reflecting the functional quality of vision in real-world conditions. Letter contrast sensitivity tests, such as the Pelli-Robson and Regan charts, use letters of constant size but gradually decreasing contrast, and are typically read at a distance of 1 meter. These help determine the lowest contrast level at which letters can still be identified.
  • Alternatively, contrast sensitivity can be tested using sinusoidal pattern gratings. Here, alternating bars of light and dark with varying spatial frequencies and contrast. The patient must determine the orientation or tilt of the bars, which becomes increasingly difficult to discern as contrast and spacing change. The performance is quantified in terms of visual angle, or "cycles per degree," indicating how many patterns fit into one degree of the visual field.

Explanation of other options:

Visual acuity (Option A): Visual acuity is evaluated by determining the smallest detail a person can resolve at a specific distance, typically using test charts like the Snellen chart, where each letter subtends a visual angle of 5 minutes.

Colour vision (Option B): Tests for colour vision include the Lantern test, Farnsworth-Munsell 100-hue test, Ishihara and other isochromatic charts, and Anomaloscopes like the Nagel and Pickford Nicholson. These tools help identify specific colour defects and assess the severity and type of colour vision anomalies. The image below shows Ishihara charts.

Visual field (Option D): Visual field defects can be assessed using the confrontation test at the bedside or more precisely mapped with perimetry. Perimetry includes kinetic testing (using moving targets to plot field extent) and static testing (using stationary stimuli of varying brightness to assess retinal sensitivity), with tools such as the Goldmann perimeter or automated computerised perimeters being commonly used.

questions.text: What does the image given below show?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image given shows myelinated nerve fibres of retinal ganglion cells.

  • Myelinated or medullated nerve fibres, seen in about 1% of individuals, involve the abnormal extension of ganglion cell axon myelination beyond the cribriform plate, detectable during fundus examination.
  • The condition is usually congenital and stable, though both progressive and acquired types exist. MNF may rarely run in families, and systemic associations are uncommon.
  • Signs include a potential reduction in visual acuity if the central macula is affected. Visual field testing may show absolute scotomas corresponding to the involved retinal regions. One or more whitish striated patches with feathered margins may be observed, varying in location and size, with two-thirds of cases not involving the optic disc.
  • Retinal vessels in affected areas are often obscured. Bilaterality occurs in 5 -10% of cases. MNF can resemble neoplastic infiltration or other retinal conditions.
  • Ocular associations encompass myopia, anisometropia, strabismus, and amblyopia.
  • Imaging features include hypoautofluorescence on fundus autofluorescence (FAF), background fluorescence masking on fluorescein angiography (FA), and a hyper-reflective retinal nerve fibre layer (RNFL) on OCT.
  • Treatment targets refractive correction, amblyopia management, and squint treatment when present.

Explanation of other options:

Bergmeister papillae (Option A): The fibrous tissue seen at the optic disc is from remnants of the hyaloid artery.

Papilledema (Option C): Papilledema is characterised by optic disc swelling on both sides due to elevated intracranial pressure, primarily caused by a blockage in axoplasmic flow. While any brain tumour can potentially cause papilledema, it is most frequently associated with masses in the cerebellum, parieto-occipital area, and midbrain.

Disc drusen (Option D): Drusen of the optic disc are often inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern and commonly affect both eyes. These calcified, laminated deposits tend to enlarge slowly over time and can make the optic disc appear similar to papilledema, even though the visual disturbances they cause may not correlate with the drusen's location.
